business.start.para: The PRESIDENT(Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

subdebateinfo.title: Environment: Kyoto Protocol

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. I refer the minister to the fifth conference of the parties to the Framework Convention on Climate Change recently held in Bonn. Can the minister confirm that some 60 countries at COP-5 committed to a timetable of ratification to allow the protocol to come into effect by 2002, and that these countries cover some 80 per cent of the emissions needed for the protocol to come into force? Can the minister further confirm that the Kyoto Protocol could come into force without ratification by the United States? I ask the minister: why then is Australia waiting for the US to ratify—a delay which could result in Australia's exclusion from the new global markets worth not billions of dollars but some trillions of dollars?

—Madam President, I said when coming down to question time, `I bet Senator Bolkus asks me a question today on the environment.' When you go for 150 days without asking a question of your opponents in this place and that then becomes public knowledge, obviously you have got to take some remedial action. Anyway, I welcome environment questions from Senator Bolkus—even if I get so few—and I am happy to talk about the issue that Senator Bolkus raised of ratification of the Kyoto Protocol.

answer.para: The facts of life are that the Kyoto Protocol will not be ratified by major players until a number of matters have been settled, including the flexibility mechanisms—which, in turn, include matters such as the CDM and emissions trading—issues of compliance and issues of sinks. It is hoped that the detail of these matters will be settled at the next conference of the parties, which in turn, it is believed, although it is not certain, will be held late next year. It should clear the way for consideration of ratification by the major emitters.

But there is one matter that, beyond issues of filling in the detail of the Kyoto Protocol, is critical to the issue of ratification, and that is third-party participation by developing countries. It is well known that without the settlement of details, such as on emissions trading, and also real commitments by large developing country emitters, the United States will not ratify. It is true that it is technically possible for enough other states to ratify without the United States, but it is simply unrealistic to expect that to occur. I say that, knowing as I do that the European Union has made some public statement to the effect that it might do so. In my view, it will not do so ahead of the United States because, by doing so, it could be economically disadvantaged; and that is just not the real world.

It is in Australia's interests to get the detail of Kyoto finally settled at the next COP and to get the Kyoto Protocol brought into legal effect as soon as possible. That is because Australia, although accepting a demanding target at Kyoto, nevertheless got a fair target, and it is unlikely that any alternative international negotiation that could potentially subsume Kyoto in the future would give to Australia an opportunity that is as fair as we were able to negotiate in Kyoto.

We are one of the countries that are actively working towards settling outstanding issues in order that ratification might be made at the earliest possible date, in order that the Kyoto Protocol might come into effect and be legally enforceable. In concluding, I make the point that I have made before: Australia, in terms of its domestic response, is not actually waiting for the Kyoto Protocol to come into effect: we are implementing programs to achieve our target, notwithstanding. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I have a supplementary question to the minister. I note that the point that some 60 countries, representing over 80 per cent of emissions, are prepared to commit to a timetable for ratification is a point that the minister chooses to ignore. I ask the minister: can he confirm that the Australian government sent a delegation of some 23 people to COP-5 in Bonn, when the government had no intention at all of ratifying the protocol? How many of the sizeable delegation were from the non-government sector? Is it a fact that there was only one? In light of the Australian government's decision not to ratify, how much did this delegation cost the taxpayer?

—Costs of delegations is something that is normally asked in estimates, and I will get the advice on that and let Senator Bolkus know in due course. It was a sizeable delegation, as every delegation has been—including the one led by Senator Faulkner that was so unsuccessful, I might say, Senator Bolkus. What you failed to tell the Senate is that most of the countries that said that they would commit to a timetable of 2002 will not even be bound by the Kyoto Protocol. They are countries that will not take new legal obligation as a result of the Kyoto Protocol, and I am sorry that you misled the Senate a little in your question in that regard, Senator.

answer.para: In relation to ratification, Senator Bolkus failed to hear what I said, and that is that Australia is keen to be in a position to be able to ratify in due course and to see the Kyoto Protocol come into effect. But we are also not going to put ourselves in an economically disadvantageous position, and I would have thought that was sensible. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Employment: Women

talk.start.para: —My question without notice is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Will the Assistant Treasurer inform the Senate of the strong jobs growth that has occurred under the Howard government and particularly of how women have benefited from the government's focus on job creation. Would the Assistant Treasurer also inform the Senate as to whether productivity gains have resulted in not only more jobs but also increased real wages for Australian families.

—I thank Senator Payne for that very important question. The most recent labour market statistics show that there are now almost 600,000 more Australians employed than there were in March 1996 when the discredited Keating government was hurled from office. The unemployment rate in October fell by 0.3 per cent to 7.1 per cent, and the participation rate has also increased over recent months. The high participation rate of women has been particularly noticeable, which reached a new record of 54.6 per cent in October. This was accompanied by the news—which will please women and particularly the questioner, Senator Payne—that the women's unemployment rate fell to 6.8 per cent in October—a nine-year low.

question.para: The government is very much aware that there is still more to be done in the area of job creation and will continue to work to build on the very important gains that have already been made. This government is very pleased to provide benefits which have flowed through to the average Australian worker. Under this government Australian workers have enjoyed significant increases in real wages—that is, they have more money in their pockets after taking account of inflation. This has been achieved while keeping inflation low. These gains to workers have been achieved through this government's commitment to productivity improvements. Productivity improvements are helping to deliver more jobs and higher real wages to ordinary Australians.

Wage increases above and beyond the cost of living are not the only benefit that workers have received under the Howard government; they have also received major benefits from the dramatic reduction in mortgage interest rates.

talk.start.para: —For executives. The CEO of Coles Myer is doing very well, thank you very much!
—Therefore, Senator George Campbell would be interested to know that workers have benefited from higher wages and lower interest rates. Labor never delivered benefits to workers.
—What figures are you quoting?

—Seeing as Senator George Campbell has made a comment, the book, Out of the Rut: Making Labor a Genuine Alternative , for which Senator George Campbell was a very distinguished writer, pointed out that Labor had left office with some 800,000 people out of work and that there was a fall in real wages. A process worker—
—What about the social welfare? What about families? What about superannuation?
—Senator George Campbell would be very interested in this matter.

question.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are Labor senators who are continuously shouting, and I ask them to abide by the standing orders.

—Madam President, I was just pointing out that Senator George Campbell would be very interested that this book showed that there was a fall in real wages such that a process worker earned $100 per week less in real terms when Labor lost office than when they won it in 1983. What an absolutely pathetic and tragic record. This government is delivering real gains and real benefits to Australian workers, and there are, of course, major tax cuts in the offing.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of a delegation from the People's Republic of China led by the Vice Minister for Health and Director General of the State Drug Administration, Mr Zheng Xiaoyu. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and I trust that your visit to this country will be both informative and enjoyable.
—Hear, hear!

subdebateinfo.title: APEC Technomart III

talk.start.para: —My question without notice is to Senator Minchin, Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. Does the Minister recall his statement on 8 November this year that in June 1999 a contract was signed between his department and PacRim Technomart setting out the details and conditions of federal government sponsorship of APEC Technomart III? Does the minister also recall stating on 16 November that part of the government's role as a sponsor of this event was `to sponsor the application for APEC badging' and that support for APEC badging was `part of being a sponsor'? Isn't the minister deliberately fudging the timing of the Commonwealth's involvement in the light of former Minister Moore's announcement of the APEC badging of the Technomart on 9 October 1998? How could APEC badging be part of the federal government's sponsorship when it had occurred eight months before the sponsorship contract was signed?

—We joined with the Queensland state Labor government in sponsoring APEC Technomart, and I did indicate that the Commonwealth government's involvement was embraced by the term `sponsorship'. When I said that, I was quite deliberately including in that description the fact that the Commonwealth did assist in sponsoring this Technomart receiving APEC endorsement. It is quite clear that the word `sponsorship', which is the way I described the government's support for this Technomart, clearly encompasses our role in assisting this organisation to secure APEC badging. In August of 1998, the then Department of Industry, Science and Tourism sponsored the proposal to secure APEC badging and invited other APEC economies to cosponsor the event.

answer.para: Sponsoring the proposal for APEC endorsement maximised the potential benefits of the government's financial sponsorship of the event. Sponsoring the APEC endorsement process was the first stage of the department's financial sponsorship of the event. Therefore, my press release of 8 November was not misleading, as the gaining of APEC endorsement was on the public record and was part of my department's more general sponsorship of this event.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Did the federal government give any other support to PacRim Technomart in relation to APEC Technomart III before the June 1999 contract was signed?

—The only advice to me in relation to that matter is the involve ment in the APEC sponsorship. I am not aware of any other particular activities, apart from the securing of APEC sponsorship. I met with the organisers at one point earlier, and no doubt Mr Moore met with them. I and one or two others would have filmed promotional videos for them. But, as far as I am aware, that was the extent of the involvement.

subdebateinfo.title: Information Technology and Telecommunications: Employment

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston. Will the minister inform the Senate of the increasing importance to jobs growth of the information technology and telecommunications sectors? Is the minister aware of industry concerns over alternative policy proposals? What would be the impact if they were implemented?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The IT&T sectors are indeed a crucial part of Australia's development and jobs potential. They currently employ in excess of 200,000 people in Australia. As a percentage of GDP, our expenditure on information technology and telecommunications is the third highest in the OECD region. The marketplace is valued at around $45 billion, which is about three per cent of the global market, which means we are punching well above our weight, and it is a larger sector than all of the ASEAN countries combined. It clearly has enormous potential. The demand for skilled employees is growing at the rate of nine per cent a year, and there are currently some 360,000 specialists employed in the IT&T sector.

answer.para: One of the concerns that has been expressed around the world is the global skills shortage. Quite clearly, Australia needs to ensure that we do everything to attract people into the sector and to have the education system produce people who not only are IT literate but also have the skills that are required in the marketplace and are able to take advantage of the significant premiums that attach to positions in this area.

When you contrast the approach that we have taken with that of our political opponents, it really is very stark and, from Australia's point of view, it really is very one-sided. For example, if one tries to explain why people are attracted offshore, one might refer to Silicon Valley, where there are innumerable job opportunities and tremendous shortages. It might also be the size of the market on the US mainland. It might simply be the excitement of networking in that region. The Labor Party's explanation for why people tend to leave Australia is this—this is what Senator Lundy had to say recently:

Young people who have these skills, who have their whole lives ahead of them, who are committed to Australia, look at the frontbench of the government and it does not inspire them to stay. Is it any wonder people look elsewhere?

So Labor's explanation for the global skills shortage and the reason for people being persuaded to go offshore is apparently to have a look at our frontbench. It makes you wonder about the state of Labor's frontbench. We know that they have had to suspend all operations to try to cobble together this employment package. It looks like now being eight or nine months behind schedule, which is rather tragic. I would have thought they could have done a lot better than that.

You have only to look at the Australian Computers editorial earlier this month to see where Labor has really got to in terms of IT&T. The heading is `Labor well behind on IT awareness', and it states:
The state and federal governments accept this reality, but Labor's politicians in Canberra struggle to grasp the enormity of this change.

I think it is fair to say that John Brumby is very interested in this area and will make a significant contribution in due course. I am delighted that he was able to persuade his short-sighted colleagues from the Premier down that somehow IT&T did deserve a mention on the front bench, a very silly mistake but one that was actually corrected within a reasonably short period of time. But we do not get anything like that sort of fleetness of foot at federal level. And that is why the editorial is absolutely correct in saying:
The Federal Government recognises this [the importance of IT] and has encouraged IT development in Australia in the past two years.
The Victorian ALP has learnt that lesson in the last two weeks. When will the penny drop within Labor's ranks in Canberra?
It is out there. I think the industry understands that there is really only one side on the playing field. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: APEC Technomart III

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Minchin, the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, and it follows on from Senator Conroy's question. Can the minister confirm that APEC Technomart III, which was to run for the first week of November on the Gold Coast, folded after two days when the company organising the conference, PacRim Technomart Inc., collapsed and the organisers went into hiding? Can the minister also confirm that Ms Judith Maestracci from PacRim Technomart was one of these organisers as the project manager of APEC Technomart III? When the federal government proposed to APEC that Australia should host APEC Technomart III and when Australia subsequently provided progress reports to APEC, was Ms Maestracci nominated as the project overseer? Did she not represent Australia and the federal government in that capacity?

—Just in answer to the three questions which are there, yes, it is on the record and well known that, regrettably and most disappointingly to the Commonwealth government, to the Queensland state Labor government, to the Gold Coast City Council and to quite a number of private sector sponsors who all joined together to help sponsor the APEC Technomart III, the event did shut down after some two days. I joined with Premier Beattie in speaking at a very useful venture capital forum there on the Wednesday, but the fact is the event was not successful. Obviously the Queensland state Labor government and we were disappointed that it was not successful. So that is a matter of record.

answer.para: It is certainly true that Ms Maestracci was one of the people involved in the private sector company which was behind this. That was always known, and it was always made clear in the Commonwealth's approach to the APEC structure that this was a private sector initiative. At no time was it ever presented as anything other than a private sector initiative which the Commonwealth hoped to be in a position to sponsor and which the Commonwealth thought would be a very good way of showcasing Australian technology, as did the Queensland Labor government.

The previous APEC Technomarts had been very successful. There was every reason to believe this would be successful. My department, as part of its general sponsorship arrangements, did conclude that this event was worth sponsoring because it had a lot of upside for showcasing Australian technology. Indeed, as Premier Beattie said to me, Ms Maestracci was well known as a very professional operator, as were the others involved, and that is why the Queensland Labor government was very willing to support this, to be fully involved and to be right behind the project.

I cannot answer as to whether or not Ms Maestracci was there when the APEC sponsorship arrangements were made or what her particular status was. I do not have that detail. I am happy to find that out for you.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I think it is important, and I would appreciate the minister establishing, whether Ms Maestracci did actually represent Australia and the federal government in the capacity as project overseer. Can the minister confirm that, while Australia's nominated APEC contact for APEC Technomart III was Ms Judith Maestracci from PacRim Technomart Inc., the nominated contacts for all other participating APEC economies were government officials from each country's respective industry department?

—I will need to take that on notice. That is the sort of level of detail which I do not have. All I will say is that it was always the case in the representations made to, and the Commonwealth government sponsorship of, APEC badging of this event that it was private sector managed and run. That is the basis on which the Queensland government assisted in seeking the APEC sponsorship and the basis on which the Queensland government got right behind it: that this was a private sector managed event which would be hopefully sponsored by a range of industry and government bodies. I will find out those details and get back to you.

subdebateinfo.title: Australia Post: Lifestyle Survey

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. I refer to the HBA Health Management Lifestyle questionnaire for Australia Post employees. Did the minister approve yet another example by Australia Post of collecting highly personal behavioural and medical information? Does he acknowledge that individual employees can be identified on this questionnaire? Minister, if the only reason for this survey is to provide staff with a health risk assessment report, why is it necessary to know what kind of vehicle they drive, the kilometres they do and how many traffic infringement notices they have had? Why are employees being asked if they are lonely or how much money they spend on Tattslotto? Minister, why are Australia Post female employees being asked if they plan a pregnancy within the next 12 months or the age at which they gave birth to their first child?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I am not aware that the department was consulted by Australia Post in the course of the preparation of this survey. There are two separate surveys, and the one that relates to employees is the Gold Post 2000 Employee Survey. I think even Senator Allison acknowledges that this is a voluntary offer. It is a survey that has its basis in the enterprise bargaining agreement. It does provide for a bonus to be paid based on attendance and wellbeing requirements. Having read the article in the Australian today which describes some of the detail, one can only assume that it is designed to assist employees in identifying those matters which might not be compatible with effective workplace performance and which may well be indicative of problems outside the workplace which might impact upon their workplace performance.

answer.para: At the end of the day, this is a voluntary survey. There is no obligation on people to comply with it. There is no suggestion that anyone would be in any way discriminated against if they did not. There are a number of very important matters addressed in that survey which all people in the workplace, or indeed, I suppose, in the wider community, would benefit from concentrating on. Even if they chose not to comply with the survey or to submit it to the employer, to address all of those issues may be a very timely warning in respect of certain lifestyle and behavioural patterns.

Beyond that, I do not know whose advice was sought by Australia Post in preparing the survey. As I did indicate yesterday, it is my understanding that the Privacy Commissioner was consulted in relation to the Australian Family Lifestyle Survey, and it may well be the case in relation to the employee survey as well.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. Minister, isn't it the case that this is not a voluntary questionnaire and that Australia Post employees do not get their EBA bonus unless they do the questionnaire? Minister, who is making money out of this exercise and how many other departments might be moving into this kind of lucrative business? How much, for instance, will the HBA pay for this sensitive information, and what assurances are you prepared to give that neither the HBA nor Australia Post will use this data for commercial purposes? Minister, I ask you today, as I did yesterday: when will your government put in place protection for people coerced into revealing this kind of personal information?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Senator Allison is very good at throwing around florid and colourful terms, but there is no suggestion of people being coerced into signing the form.
—They are being coerced.

—Well, I know the union movement always likes to suggest that somehow you need to be rescued from a whole range of people because you really are not in any fit position to look after yourself or to make your own arrangements or to decide whether to fill in a survey and that what you really need is someone from the union standing over your shoulder telling you how to behave, telling you how to organise your affairs, telling you how to run your lifestyle. It is quite incorrect for Senator Allison to say that this is a compulsory survey. You do not need to fill it in and submit it before obtaining a bonus. The arrangements are that the bonus payments depend upon two things: meeting the attendance requirement and a workplace score of at least 50 per cent of the total points that could be scored on lifestyle elements. So this could occur if all employees score at least 50 per cent or if half of the employees score 100 per cent or some other combination. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: APEC Technomart III

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Minchin, the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. Was the minister informed of and did he approve the make-up of the Australian delegation to the 16th APEC Industry Science and Technology Working Group meeting in Hong Kong on or about 3 March 1999? Did the Australian delegate list include four senior officials from the Department of Industry, Science and Resources, including one senior official acting as `lead shepherd', using APEC terminology? Did the Australian delegate list also include Ms Judith Maestracci from PacRim Technomart?

—That again goes to the detail which I do not have. I certainly did not know of or approve any delegation list to APEC, the membership of the delegation—I can certainly answer that with confidence. Again, the question of Ms Maestracci's role or otherwise is a detail about which in the previous answer I said I would have to come back to you. I would take this opportunity to point out that the formal written proposal put to APEC did say in its opening paragraph:

answer.para: The proposal is for Australia to host the next APEC Technomart . . . as a commercially sponsored, managed and administered event.
The front page of the proposal also stated:

The event, unlike other APEC Technomarts, will be funded primarily by the private sector. Major sponsors have already been secured. Exhibitors will be required to pay for space. There will be some financial support from the Australian and Queensland Governments.
Of course, the Queensland government joined with us in so doing. It endorsed APEC involvement. As I said, on 12 October 1998 the Queensland Deputy Premier, Mr Jim Elder, said:
At our end, this was a project supported by my government through the Department of State Development and this government—
the Queensland state Labor government—
endorsement and involvement has helped sway the APEC countries.

So this was always from the very outset and throughout the submission the proposal to APEC. It was made quite clear this was a commercially sponsored run and managed event. It was different from the previous two APEC Technomarts; it was a private sector managed affair. That was always open and upfront. That is why the Queensland state Labor government and the Commonwealth government both sponsored it on that basis and were both upfront in their representations to APEC on that basis. In terms of the delegation, I will have to get that information for you. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the minister's earlier answer where it appears that he did not acknowledge the level of support that was given by the federal government to PacRim Technomart, I now ask: what other support, financial or in kind, did the federal government give to Ms Maestracci or PacRim Technomart Inc. in organising APEC Technomart III?

—I think I have been quite open and upfront about this in my responses to Mr McMullan's press releases, as I have answered all his questions in my press releases that I have given in response to his accusations.
—I am asking my questions, which you are not answering at all.

—We have been quite upfront. I said that the Commonwealth Department of Industry, Science and Resources sponsored this event to the tune of some $200,000, and the department incurred in addition to that its own expenses of some $65,400—
—If you don't know, take it on notice.
—Senator Faulkner, cease shouting.
—Will you let me answer the question? I do know. I am giving you the answer you want.

answer.para: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

talk.start.para: —$65,400 of costs in relation to its own—
—Madam President, I rise on a point of order.
—Order! Senators on my left will cease making so much noise.
—Is it in order for Senator Faulkner to say twice `You're lying' across the table?
—If he said it, it is not in order and I would ask him to withdraw it.
—If I said it, Madam President, I withdraw it. But I would ask the minister to answer the question.
—Senator Faulkner, you ought not to be interjecting during the answer to a question.

—Senator Faulkner asked me the details of the sponsorship which are already on the public record. There was $200,000 of sponsorship of the event and some expenditure of $65,400 within my department in relation to its own participation in APEC Technomart III.

subdebateinfo.title: Illegal Immigration: People Smuggling

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. Considering the government's proposed tightening of the laws to stop people smuggling and recognising the fact that Pauline Hanson's One Nation advocated similar changes over a year ago, due to the current influx of illegal entries into Australia by boat—and this could not proceed without some form of contact within Australia—would the minister inform the Senate how the government intends to identify those people and take actions again them?

—I thank the senator for his question. Senator, it would be possible for people to assist and organise the trafficking or smuggling of persons into Australia without their necessarily having contacts here. That remains fairly obvious, I think, to the vast majority of people who have had a close interest in this over a period of time.

answer.para: The method is simply this: get a number of people to a nearby country, for example, Indonesia; have organisers in Indonesia who can lay their hands on boats that might either be cargo vessels or appear to be fishing vessels; take those vessels with the cargo of misery attached to Ashmore Reef or Christmas Island; and, if you are unable to land, as soon as you see an Australian boat with people on board, just disable your own boat—that is, sink the boat. If you cannot land, sink it, because no Australian will sit by and watch a number of people simply drown in the Indian Ocean. Once the people are on Ashmore Reef, they are brought to Australia and they are dealt with by immigration authorities.

So it is not actually true that one requires assistance on the mainland in order to achieve the successful arrival in Australia of immigrants over the marine border illegally. It is, however, possible that that is the case. All I choose to say with respect to that is that every avenue to pursue people who are possibly engaging in such activity is being used. If at any time I have some further detail that it would be appropriate to make public, I will.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the minister assure the Australian people that the measures introduced are strong enough to ensure that only bona fide refugees are eligible to remain in Australia and obtain access to Australia's free health, legal and welfare system?

—Senator, there have been some squabbles over the years—irrespective of who has been in government—over the handling of refugees. But there is bipartisan agreement on this: those people who are genuine refugees should be able to stay in Australia and those people who are not should be repatriated as quickly as possible. Both governments have attempted to achieve that.

subdebateinfo.title: Health: MRI Scans

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Herron in his capacity as the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Is the minister aware that he is currently in contempt of the Senate for his failure to provide certain documents relating to the MRI scandal by 3 p.m. yesterday afternoon, as required by the order of the Senate agreed on 21 October? Is the minister aware that he has compounded his contempt for the Senate by not producing any reason to the Senate for his refusal to produce the documents? Is the minister aware that, according to advice provided by the Clerk of the Senate, it is unprecedented that any minister has so blatantly defied the Senate by not explaining the grounds for the non-disclosure? Does the minister have any excuse that he can give the Senate today?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The minister is very interested in pursuing the MRI matters, as are all senators, and notes the importance that the Senate has attached to the MRI issue. I think all of us are concerned about the issue itself and we share the concern that Senator Evans has asked us about. We are concerned that a scam may have been committed in relation to this matter by some radiologists. As Senator Evans is aware, the government has introduced a number of measures in relation to MRI.
—Madam President, I raise a point of order. While I appreciate that the minister may have suddenly found some concern for this matter, having previously failed to take an interest—
—What is your point of order, Senator?

—The question was about the failure to reply to the return to order. In the first couple of minutes he has not addressed the question of why the return to order has not been complied with. That is the question.
—The minister has had less than one minute so far in which to respond, but I draw his attention to the substance of the question.

—I got through three sentences of the reply; I do not think I had even 30 seconds. If Senator Evans is interested in the answer, I am happy to provide it, but I should be given the opportunity to do so. I will reply in the manner in which I wish to reply to the question, not the manner in which Senator Evans is trying to insist.

answer.para: I am making the point that there is a degree of concern about this matter by the minister, and the minister has spoken about that. The minister has instituted an inquiry into the matter. Senator Evans is not going to be judge, jury and executioner in relation to this matter, which is what he is implying. He has asked for documents. There is an inquiry in place. The Senate has asked for a range of documents, those being: the dates on which the MRI machines were ordered; the minutes of the meeting between the department and the college of radiologists; and advice received by the Minister for Health and Aged Care on MRI rebates. Is Senator Evans interested in an outcome for the Senate and for the people of Australia in relation to this matter, or does he want to conduct a political witch hunt? That is the question.

Given the range of investigations that are already in place into the MRI issue, it would not be appropriate to table documents that are central to the investigation process. That is the answer to his question: it would not be appropriate to table documents that are central to the investigation process.

The Minister for Health and Aged Care has already indicated that he and his office, including both past and present staff, will cooperate fully with the Auditor-General's inquiry. The Auditor-General is conducting an inquiry, and it should be left to the Auditor-General to proceed with that unfettered by possible political point scoring and judgment by Senator Evans.

The government would not want to compromise any of the investigations already under way and for that reason will not comply with the Senate order to produce documents at this stage. When it is in the interests of the Senate to receive the documents, then that determina tion will be made. Surely the opposition, if they were an opposition with any intelligence, would want an outcome of this investigation that was—

talk.start.para: —You said there was no problem. You are on the Hansard as saying there was no problem.

—I am on the Hansard , and at that period we did not know of a problem. I do not accept allegations, and there is still an inquiry. Senator Evans is prejudging the outcome of an inquiry. As I said, there is a process in place; there has been an inquiry established by the Auditor-General and we will await the outcome of that inquiry.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I appreciate that the minister has finally condescended to give the Senate a reason as to why he has not complied with the return to order. Why has the minister also not answered the questions on notice relating to MRI, which are three or four weeks overdue and which I contacted his office about last week? Is this part of the government's continuing cover-up of the MRI scandal? Will we get the information about the MRI scandal that we and the public are entitled to know?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —We keep getting these emotive words that there is a scandal. There is an inquiry. The same answer that I gave before is related to the supplementary question: the inquiry has been instituted by the Auditor-General and the investigations into the issue are already in place. I did not say that there was a scandal, nor did I admit there was any scandal. I am prepared to await the outcome of the inquiry. Senator Evans says it is a scandal. It is possible that one exists, but I would have thought that one needs evidence before an inquiry. I respect the inquiry of the Auditor-General and that is the process that will continue.

subdebateinfo.title: Information Technology: Outsourcing

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, Senator Ellison. Will the minister inform the Senate of the achievements of the government's information outsourcing programs which have saved taxpayers money and supported small and medium enterprises? Is the minister aware of any recent public statements relating to these outsourcing initiatives? If so, do they accurately reflect the facts?

—I thank Senator Coonan for that very important question. It is timely indeed because today the Minister for Finance and Administration addressed a very large gathering in Canberra—the Asian-Oceanian Computing Industry Organisation—in relation to this very topic. Today the Minister for Finance and Administration outlined how our IT outsourcing program to date would save taxpayers more than $320 million over a five-year period. That is good news for taxpayers in Australia, but there is more. Our outsourcing program to date will also see around $265 million paid to small and medium Australian enterprises. Further to that, to date $850 million will be value added to Australian goods and services. It will also provide to date $260 million in new exports or import replacements. That spells good news for the IT industry in Australia. What is more, our program on IT outsourcing to date will also create 380 jobs in regional Australia. What do the opposition say about this? Nothing. What the opposition want to do is to place IT outsourcing on hold.

answer.para: Senator Lundy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Persistent interjecting is disorderly.

—They do not want to see these jobs developed; they do not want to see the exports I have mentioned; they do not want to see those benefits to small and medium enterprises. In fact, when you look at the interview which Senator Lundy gave just yesterday in Canberra, you see that it referred to an Auditor's report—which I have here—as authority for this so-called `flawed' outsourcing program. But, of course, what Senator Lundy did not tell the interviewer was that this report related only to the following things: building and facilities maintenance, cleaning services, security services, finance and/or travel services, advertising, and internal audit. There was no mention of IT outsourcing in this report.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I point out to Labor senators that constantly shouting during an answer to a question is disorderly.

—As the interview went on, Senator Lundy cited this report from the Auditor-General as an authority, saying that the IT outsourcing program by the government was flawed and that it should not be continued. There was no such thing said. In fact, Senator Lundy went on to say there were four reports being undertaken by the Auditor-General's office in relation to the outsourcing of IT programs. Of course, this is normal. Whenever we outsource IT programs, the Auditor-General—through you, Madam President, to Senator Lundy—conducts a review.

answer.para: Senator Lundy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Lundy, there is an appropriate time to debate this issue and it is not by constantly shouting during question time.

—When you look at that interview, you see that Senator Lundy is trying to portray that there is a big problem with our IT outsourcing and that the Auditor-General is looking into it. What the Auditor-General is doing is simply going about his job and doing a routine review of outsourcing.

answer.para: Senator Lundy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Lundy is not having a good question time today, but she has persistently interjected on Senator Ellison. I ask you to call her to order again or to remove her. She has been interjecting constantly.
—I am noting the behaviour of certain persons, Senator.

—Senator Lundy was asked about—and I note that Senator Lundy has had some comments today about this—how small and medium enterprises benefit. The presenter said the argument is that by grounding bigger companies, which can handle such large contracts, there is a flow-on to smaller companies via these larger companies. And Senator Lundy said, `Yes, that is of course the argument.' They put, as you know, a clause in the contracts to actually achieve that. So what Senator Lundy was saying we have already done. We have put clauses in those contracts to ensure that small and medium enterprises get the business.

answer.para: Senator Lundy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Lundy, I am speaking to you. I have already drawn your attention to the fact that you are in breach of the standing orders by persistently and wilfully ignoring them. I draw your attention to the clauses of the standing order.

—If the Labor opposition and Senator Lundy look closely at the contracts, they would see that major contractors are required to deliver levels of work to small and medium enterprises, as I have indicated. This spells good news for the IT industry in Australia. What the opposition and Senator Lundy should do is stick to the facts and not mislead people in radio interviews about our IT outsourcing program.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: State Imposts

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. How does the minister explain insurers being forced to charge GST on fire levies, with stamp duties on top of that, when the Howard government promised that the GST would not be a tax on a tax? Is the minister aware that Mr Rod Hill, a tax expert with Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu has said:

question.para: The insurance industry is daily sending out notices incorporating a tax on a tax on a tax, thus forcing the affordability of insurance off the agenda for many Australians.

Given this fact, what does the government plan to do to stop the clear cascading effect of the GST, which the government promised would not happen and which puts insurance out of the reach of hardworking Australian families?

talk.start.para: —Thank you to Senator Mackay for the question. There was a question asked along these lines to the Treasurer in the other place today. There will be no GST on paying taxes. A GST will not apply to income tax or anything else listed in the Treasurer's determination under division 81 of the GST act.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are far too many senators participating.
—This issue has been raised a number of times in this chamber by Senator Mackay, and the government is currently consulting with the states, territories and local government—
—It's too late!
—Senator Conroy, it is not your turn to speak.

—To identify those government taxes and charges which should not be subject to GST. All levels of government have been closely involved in this process. My advice is that there has been a broad agreement reached on the draft list. I will check whether there is any further information I can provide to Senator Mackay. In determining the taxes and charges that will not be subject to GST, regard will be had to the following principles. Those taxes and charges which are in the nature of a compulsory impost for general purposes, such as local government rates, should not be subject to GST, and those regulatory charges that do not relate to a particular supply of goods and services should not be subject to GST.

answer.para: The Treasurer proposes to release by the end of the year a determination listing all the taxes and charges that will not be subject to GST. I think that should clarify the position for Senator Mackay. Someone said to me that Senator Mackay was the shadow minister for local government. I think that will come as a bit of a surprise to people in this chamber because she never seems to ask Senator Ian Macdonald a question. But we are always happy to hear from you, Senator Mackay.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I have a supplementary question. I appreciate that the minister is consulting, but can he confirm that a number of states, led by the Liberal government of Mr Court in Western Australia, have already decided to exploit the GST by applying state stamp duties to the Howard-Lees GST, thus significantly increasing state revenues? Isn't this an example of government sponsored price exploitation that would be subject to ACCC prosecution if it were done by a private sector business? In light of this, why is the federal government allowing this to occur now?

—Again, I do not think Senator Mackay is particularly well informed. There is an issue that the states have recognised. There is an argument that imposing a stamp duty on a GST inclusive basis could result in a windfall gain to state revenue. Senator, Michael Egan—who is not on my side of the chamber; he is on your side of the chamber—said that it could well be that, if there is a windfall for all of the states, there is a case for the states to vary the current stamp duty rates to take that into account. I do not think that the Labor Party has any policy to remove stamp duty.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on my left, shouting as they are, are behaving in a disorderly fashion.
—I would be very interested to hear whether there is any Labor Party policy to remove stamp duties. I am not aware that there is. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Airports: Ayers Rock

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to Senator Macdonald, the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Is the minister aware that the man who recently had the full confidence of the government as the Chairman of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, Dick Smith, says that the lack of a radio operator service at Yulara airport near Ayers Rock is a danger to the public? Has the minister seen the Civil Aviation Safety Authority media release which states that Mr Smith is wrong and there is no problem? Minister, who are we to believe? Six months ago, Dick Smith ran the entire air safety program for Australia. Surely he knows what he is talking about. Does the government agree with Mr Smith's claim that Ayers Rock airport is `an accident waiting to happen'?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —Senator Woodley has an ongoing interest in matters relating to aviation safety. He asked me about Yulara, Mr Smith's comments and the government's approach to the issue. We certainly reject the suggestion by Mr Smith that it is unsafe, and so do both of the airlines. The matter was, as Senator Woodley would know, recently subject to a trial which was funded by both Qantas and Ansett. We are assured that there is absolute safety at Yulara. I am concerned that Mr Smith was advising tourists that it was unsafe to go to Yulara. That, of course, does not do much for our tourism industry, particularly in a part of Australia that is very significant—one that we are very proud to claim as an Australian icon and one that we want tourists to attend. I do reject the claims that the airspace around Yulara airport is unsafe. Qantas and Ansett continue to investigate the area to make further improvements to air services and air safety, and it is an issue that is always monitored closely by the government.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I do thank the minister for his answer. Minister, I presume the trial is the new air traffic radio system at Ayers Rock and Jandakot airports. If it is, don't you think there is a certain contradictory nature to CASA's release in that they say, `There is no problem, but nevertheless we are having to trial some additional safety measures'? It seems to me that there is a contradiction there. I do not know whether you would agree with me or whether you could comment on that.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —As I understand the history of this matter, these issues have been raised by Mr Smith in the past. The airlines have undertaken a trial of the radio operators. That trial, as Senator Woodley would well know, is being evaluated at the moment. Senator Woodley, I can only repeat that CASA has assured me that operations at Yulara airport are safe.
—Will you fly in the area?

—Yes, I would fly in the area, and I have flown in the area, as many Australians do. There was a suggestion that some pressure was being put on aviation safety. I want to make clear that we will not tolerate pressure from any quarter to compromise aviation safety. CASA is not controlled by the airlines. As I say, Qantas and Ansett have been extremely supportive of the recent trial of the certified air-ground radio operator arrangement at Yulara, and they have contributed to the cost.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—I wish to inform the Senate that, as of yesterday, the proceedings of the Senate are being broadcast live on the Internet. With the leave of the Senate, I would incorporate in Hansard the remainder of my statement on the matter.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—
I wish to inform the Senate that, as from yesterday, the proceedings of the Senate are being broadcast live on the Internet.

In addition to the Senate Proceedings the live Internet service will also be simultaneously broadcasting the proceedings of the House of Representatives, the Main Committee of the House of Representatives, and up to four committee hearings.

Text information about the Parliament, initially Hansard reports and transcripts, but now a wide range of material on the workings of both Houses has been available on the Internet since 1995. Until now, however that information has been text or "still" images.
The Parliament's Internet site is being extensively used with an average of more than one million "hits" per month throughout 1999.

With recent developments in Internet technology, it is now possible cost-effectively to broadcast across the Internet television coverage of proceedings of the Senate, the House of Representatives and committees.
The number of Australian households connected to the Internet continues to grow and, increasingly, new and existing Internet users have personal computers capable of downloading video material.

The Internet is accessible to people in most areas of Australia particularly rural and regional areas, and offers the Parliament the opportunity to provide uninterrupted access to its proceedings free of editing, interpretation or abbreviation.
The introduction of the Internet broadcast service is another important step in meeting the objective of taking the Parliament to the people.
The Internet broadcast service can be accessed via the Parliament Home Page which is: WWW.APH.GOV.AU.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: State Imposts

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) to a question without notice asked by Senator Mackay today, relating to the goods and services tax.

Senator Mackay raised an important issue in a question to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, relating to the charging of a GST on fire levies and the application of stamp duties—in other words, a tax on a tax on a tax. This is a further major example of the problems with the application of a GST—the important principle of a tax on a tax. This was an issue which the Liberal-National coalition assured the Australian people would not occur in respect of a GST. They assured the Australian people there would not be a tax on a tax.

It is a grossly unfair situation where, for example, a GST is added to the cost of the purchase of small businesses, residential homes, insurance policies, property leases and those sorts of financial transactions and then, on top of that, there are various state charges, taxes, levies or whatever they may be called. This in effect is a tax on a tax. To magnify the difficulty that this causes, it is a percentage tax on top of a percentage tax. And what was Senator Kemp's response to this further example of a major problem that has emerged with the GST? Senator Kemp's response was that they would be consulting with state governments to try and establish some guidelines for the application of the GST in these circumstances.

This is not good enough. This problem has arisen in other countries. The government was forewarned of the difficulties that this would present. Indeed, I can recall the Liberal Party assuring the people of Australia in the lead-up to the last election that these sorts of state taxes and charges would be abolished and would be replaced by the GST. Not only have they not been abolished, their impact has been added to with a double whammy—and, in some cases, the triple whammy of a tax on a tax on a tax. Senator Kemp referred to the Premier of Western Australia, Mr Richard Court. The Premier of Western Australia said that stamp duty had always been applied after Commonwealth taxes had been levied. I quote the Financial Review:
`The principle is uniform,' he said. `In some cases [particularly on car purchases] stamp duty will decrease, in other cases it will increase.'

The point at issue here is that we have never had a GST in this country before. We have not had a federal tax apply to a whole range of transactions, such as residential home purchase, insurance policies, purchase of a small business, a mortgage and property leases. We have never had a federal tax apply in this area before. The wholesale sales tax, which the Liberal Party is so fond of criticising, did not apply in those areas. So we have a new tax, and then state taxes applying on top of the GST. This is grossly unfair. It is ludicrous for the Liberal Premier of Western Australia, Mr Court, to say that this has always happened. It has not always happened, because we have not had a GST.

The Liberal Premier of Western Australia, Mr Court, would have known this well. He has been a strong advocate of a GST. It is no wonder, when his government is intending to apply the unfortunate principle of a tax on a tax on a tax. This is not the only recent example we have had. We have also had the latest saga, reported in the Financial Review, of renovated houses, which could attract a GST, depending on the extent of renovations. A draft business activity statement to be filled out by more than the one million new tax collectors—small businesses in this country—is two pages long, but the instructions are 130 pages long.

talk.start.para: —What is your policy?

—Our policy is not a GST—a massive new tax, a massive new set of problems and headaches for small business in this country. Labor's policy is not a tax on a tax on a tax—a percentage tax on a percentage tax. The Liberal Party promised a simplified tax system and what have we got? We have a more complex tax system. It is going to cost small business more to administer and what do they get in return? They get a paltry $200 to assist in this—(Time expired)

—It is quite clear that there is very real embarrassment, especially among Labor senators from Tasmania, given that the regional forest agreement legislation will be before the Senate today and during the course of this week. What this, of course, has to do with the debate before us is that Senator Sherry, in desperation, will look at any issue other than to explain to the Tasmanian people why he and the Tasmanian Labor senators are not supporting the regional forest agreement legislation.

—Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order on relevance. Senator Abetz is starting to talk about the Regional Forest Agreement and it is really drawing a long bow to go from the GST to regional forest agreements.

—This is usually a wide-ranging debate. However, I would ask Senator Abetz to endeavour—and I am sure that he is going to—to bring his response in line with Senator Mackay's question and Senator Kemp's reply.

—Madam Deputy President, as I was pointing out, Senator Sherry—and this is borne out by his point of order—has highlighted the fact that he and his Labor colleagues in Tasmania are highly embarrassed that they have been rolled on this legislation by the federal parliamentary Labor Party in contradistinction to the view of the trade union movement and state Labor in Tasmania. Senator Sherry therefore had to cast around for another issue to try to divert attention from his gross embarrassment.

speech.para: His gross embarrassment was further highlighted by Senator Kay Patterson's very articulate interjection. She said, `Senator Sherry, what is your policy?' We then heard a diatribe that lasted for ages, with a raised voice, telling us everything that the Labor Party policy was not. He could not quite get around to the point of explaining what is Labor's tax policy—and, of course, there is none. The people of Australia are entitled to know what the Labor Party's policy on taxation is. If what we are putting forward is so bad, then fine—but then tell us what your alternatives are.

talk.start.para: —The Toorak tractors.

—Yes, the Toorak tractor policy at the last election was jettisoned and a capital gains tax policy was jettisoned, only to be followed by the jettisoning of the shadow Treasurer at the time, Gareth Evans, who is now right out of the parliament. This is their policy making at its best. Senator Sherry is following in that great tradition of Labor Party tax policy formulation in just trying to take cheap shots at the government but without presenting any alternative to the Australian people.

speech.para: If he is so concerned about state taxes, why doesn't he pick up the blower to Tasmanian Premier Jim Bacon and say, `Remove the stamp duties'? But, of course, he knows what would happen if he picked up the phone to Premier Jim Bacon. The Premier would be saying to Senator Sherry and his Labor colleagues, `Why are you going to vote down the regional forest agreement legislation today, which will cost Tasmanian workers?' Fifteen per cent of Tasmanians are employed in the forest industry and Senator Sherry and his Tasmanian colleagues have sold them out and put the axe right through the possibility of investment.
Senator Calvert interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Calvert quite correctly reminds me that people such as Michelle O'Byrne, the temporary member for Bass, and Sid Sidebottom and Dick Adams are highly embarrassed about Labor's lack of policy in a whole host of areas. But the one time that they do get into a policy situation, like on forestry, they get it absolutely wrong and sell out regional and rural Australia, particularly Tasmania. They just happen to think they can take Tasmania for granted because they did relatively well at the last election, but I would remind them that the people of Tasmania will be very mindful of the betrayal of the Labor Party on this issue.

speech.para: Any Labor member or senator who gets up in this debate should tell the Australian people what their policy is. It is not good enough to tell us what their policy is not; we want to know what their actual policy is and we want a guarantee that they will not reject it—like they rejected their Toorak tractor tax, the capital gains tax and, above all, their former shadow Treasurer, Gareth Evans. The Australian people deserve better in debates on taxation, and it is up to the Australian Labor Party to tell the people of Australia what their policy is. If they do not have anything affirmative to say, they should not be involved in this debate.

talk.start.para: —What an embarrassing and pathetic attempt, Senator Abetz, to try to cobble your government's response together—

—Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Besides being painfully hurtful, Senator Crossin should in fact be directing her comments through the chair. That way, she would not be quite as personal and offensive.
—Please address the chair, Senator Crossin.

—Madam Deputy President, through you, what an embarrassing and painful attempt by Senator Abetz to try to cobble together a response in relation to what Senator Sherry had said. We raised an issue today, and I stand to take note of the Assistant Treasurer's response in relation to a question from Sue Mackay. It is a typical response from the government. All you get is a sidestepping attempt to avoid the real issue, and that is that the GST has fallen flat on its face. It is about as flat as a blancmange that has not worked. Eric Abetz can go on and on about—
—Order! Please refer to members by their correct title.

—Senator Abetz can go on and on about the last federal election campaign. We on this side wish he would, because as the federal campaign director in Tasmania he scored zero out of five, if my memory serves me right, in terms of returning Liberal Party members back to the House of Representatives. So he has a fabulous track record of being able to deliver for us.

speech.para: But let us just have a look at the Assistant Treasurer's response today. We now know that there are seven rates under the GST. I just remind people who are listening that the Assistant Treasurer sat down after less than two minutes today in responding to this question from Senator Mackay. He couldn't take his full time, probably didn't want to take his full time, because this government does not want to know and does not want to accept what is happening with the GST.

Despite their election promise to simplify the tax system, the government has revealed in certain cases that the GST is in fact a tax on a tax. Where a state or local government applies a levy, a fee or a charge for a service provided, the GST will apply on top of that levy, fee or charge. My colleagues are right, in that we heard the government say that it would seek to get the states and territories to abolish those stamp duties, and we can see that that is not happening.

An example of those levies, fees and charges that are expected to have GST added on them are fire levies contained in insurance policies, environmental levies, bushland acquisition levies, camping fees, national park entry fees, swimming pool entry fees—even sporting fields that are hired from local councils you will pay a GST on—community hire halls from local councils and library fees. In these cases the GST will be a tax on a tax.

In some states—such as Victoria—the fire service levy will be hit by the GST and both of these will be hit by stamp duty. So in these states consumers will be hit by a triple tax—a tax on a tax on a tax. We know the property and insurance industries recently have reacted very angrily to the revelation that states propose to charge stamp duty on and after a GST basis—effectively a tax on a tax. I have with me an article from the Financial Review of 26 October, which talks about the complexities for higher insurance premiums being paid by people. It says:
The complexities of the proposed GST legislation, rather than malpractice on the part of insurance companies, have caused the cost of general insurance to skyrocket, according to a GST expert.
That expert, Mr Rod Hill, said:
"The insurance industry is daily sending out notices incorporating—
in his words—
a tax, on a tax, on a tax . . .
He said:
. . . insurers have been forced to charge GST on stamp duty and fire levies due to the vagaries—
his words—
of the draft GST laws.
"The insurance industry is daily sending out notices incorporating a tax on a tax on a tax, thus forcing the affordability of insurance off the agenda for many Australians."

Many Australians know that. If you have a 12-month renewal notice coming through your post office box at this point, from November to November, then the GST kicks in. It kicks in twice if you live in those states or territories that do have such things as fire service levies. The article continues:
The impact of the cascading tax varies from State-to-State but is most marked in rural Victoria—
Senator McGauran—
where a $49 fire service levy is charged on every $100 . . .
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am not going to attack Senator Crossin. She is a soft target, metaphorically and physically, but I am not going to attack her, as she attacked Senator Abetz.
—Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. You might like to remind Senator Lightfoot that he might like to withdraw some of those remarks and direct his comments through the chair.
—I think that you had better address your remarks through the chair, Senator Lightfoot. I would urge caution in your language and how you describe other members in this place, please.
—I always take very seriously your cautions, Madam Deputy President, and when I do I have found that I am often a far better person because I did.

speech.para: The GST is a tax that is going to work. These attacks on the tax really are to cover and to try to bring down what is going to be an evolutionary tax for Australia. Those on the opposite side know that this is going to work. This is a new tax system that is going to work, just like the motor vehicle industry is going to boom as a result of this tax—not retrogress, as it did under the Labor Party, but boom. We are going to have a boom situation with the motor industry, and we are going to have a boom situation with other areas of the Australian economy. There is no GST on exports. We did not tax exports. We are removing the tax on exports.

We are worried about jobs. I have said before that this party is the champion of the working class. This party represents the working class. We represent the blue-collar vote now. You have lost it. Just as you have lost over 50 per cent of your union membership in the last few decades, so you are losing the working class vote too. The government, of course, is keeping a close eye on the motor vehicle industry and adjusting it where it sees that that transitional effect is necessary.

But you cannot say that the Premier of New South Wales is not on your side; you cannot say the Premier of Queensland is not on your side; you cannot say the Premier of Victoria is not also on your side; you cannot say the Premier of Tasmania, where Senator Sherry comes from, is not also philosophically agreeing with you. Why do you not ask those premiers if they are going to remove their stamp duty and so on? What is it that you expect from the other premiers that you do not expect from your own premiers?
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You are talking about sledging the Australian premiers with `a tax on a tax', as you so repetitively and boringly call it, but you are not prepared to say that the new tax system itself is a tax that benefits the states. You may not be aware that I represent Western Australia here. Over 10 years Western Australia is expected to get $2 billion extra as a result of the GST. We expect exports from the premier exporting state in the nation to increase to the betterment of places like Tasmania, which Senator Sherry represents.

speech.para: There is a proposition that accommodation taxes be abolished by 1 July 2000—no bed tax. We are going to take the bed tax away. There is an agreement with Mr Carr in New South Wales. Financial institutions duty and stamp duty on quoted marketable securities are to be abolished by 1 July. This is all part of the transitional period. Even you, Senator Crossin, should be intelligent enough to know that you cannot on the stroke of midnight change completely—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Lightfoot, please address the chair.

—As part of the transition, financial institutions duty and stamp duty on quoted marketable securities will be abolished by 1 July 2000. Debits tax is to be abolished by 1 July 2005. That is subject to a review by a ministerial council which comprises all the state premiers, including Labor premiers. States will receive all of the revenue from the GST.

speech.para: Why is it that you are opposed to the GST? You are opposed to it not because it will not work but because you know it is going to work; you know it is going to be a boon to the states; you know it is going to be a boon to the economy and a boon to employment. That is why you are knocking it. You want to bring Australia down while the coalition government is here in Canberra in order for us to be seen not to be competent, when we are probably the best government this nation has seen in the postwar years. I am a great fan of Robert Menzies—(Time expired).

talk.start.para: —I think the people on the opposite side have completely missed the point of the debate this afternoon. It is about three things. Firstly, it is about a tax on a tax that is applying now. If you had listened to the question that came from my colleague Senator Mackay, you would have realised that she asked about a tax on a tax that is applying now, and she quoted Mr Rod Hill who said that the insurance industry is issuing notices daily and that people are paying those notices—
—Right now.

—Right now. So we are talking about a tax on a tax that is applying now, particularly to insurance, and that in the near future will apply to property, even prior to 1 July next year. Secondly, there is no compensation for this tax whatsoever. And, thirdly, it was avoidable had this government foreseen the effect of the GST on state taxes. Those are the three points: it is a tax on a tax that is operating now; there is no compensation; and it was avoidable.

speech.para: My colleagues who spoke before me, Senator Sherry and Senator Crossin, have clearly pointed out that this tax on a tax is applying throughout a number of states of Australia. It has a significant effect when it comes to notices that are being issued for taxation in the area of stamp duty. I will point out how that applies in a moment. It will apply to property progressively as time goes on. As contracts are entered into in the period prior to 1 July, the operators will be obliged to include in those contracts an element of GST which will attract stamp duty in those property dealings. Clearly the government has failed to deliver on its promise that there would be no tax on a tax. It has nothing to do with Labor Party policy; it is to do with the government's promise that there would be no tax on a tax.

There is no compensation either now or in the future for the tax on the tax—the tax on the tax that is happening this very day. There is no compensation whatsoever, neither now nor in the future. Any compensation packages were worked out prior to this becoming a problem for the government. So those people renewing their insurance policies now and paying the stamp duty on the GST will not be compensated for that in any way. Those people who enter into property deals prior to 1 July or post 1 July which attract stamp duty on their transactions will not have any compensation whatsoever. So we have a dilemma for people—from battlers to business people—that has not been addressed and was not even foreseen by this government.

A couple of examples bring clearly to mind what this is about. If you look at a home in Western Australia costing $141,000, the stamp duty on that will increase by $233 as a result of the tax on the tax. If you look at an apartment in Sydney costing $350,000, that cost will increase by $787.50 as a result of the tax on the tax. Those amounts will not be compensated for by this government. Then if you look at the business end, the cost of an investment in a plant or factory worth $1.5 million in Newcastle will increase by $8,250. That is certainly not insignificant.

But it was avoidable, because the government had the opportunity to not have this mess occur in the first place. If there had not been the grubby deal between the Democrats and the government in the first instance, we would not have seen this happen. We would have seen a proper scrutiny of the legislation before this chamber, and issues such as this would have been picked up.

But the federal government will not accept responsibility. They want to put the blame now on the state governments. Of course, if there were no GST, this problem would not be in existence in the first place. It is because of the legislation of this government that the problem exists, and so they have got to face up to it and do something about it. They can take actions with the state government which can overcome the problem. But the problem exists today; and how to redress the problem is something that faces this government. There is a tax on a tax, and there is no compensation. The fact that it was avoidable and that the government failed to address it is totally their fault, and the blame lies with the government on this issue. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Senator Hogg finished by saying that this government should face up to its tax policies. Well, for four years now, Senator Hogg, the opposition has come into this chamber and not once has it come in with an alternative policy. You have been negative for those four years. From this side of the chamber we have called for your alternative policies. But I am happy to say that you do have an alternative policy with regard to tax: it is the wholesale sales tax. So, for the first time in four years, we can say that you actually do have an alternative policy and that, if you are re-elected to government, you will return wholesale sales tax—that iniquitous tax, that inconsistent tax, that complex tax, that debilitating tax on exporters and on our manufacturing and production sector.

speech.para: Yesterday you came in here with feigned concern for the car industry. Well, talk about a tax on a tax on a tax! Your wholesale sales tax is just that, Senator Hogg and Senator Sherry. When you buy an imported car, wholesale sales tax goes on top of the stamp duty too. That is a tax on a tax. Throw in the tariff, and you have got a triple tax.

talk.start.para: —I rise on a point of order, Madam Deputy President, and it goes to relevance. The issue is the tax on a tax: the GST, not the wholesale sales tax. The GST is going on everything and double taxation is applying. That is the issue, and he should be brought back to the question.

—On that point of order, quite obviously Senator Sherry is wrong. Senator McGauran must be allowed to develop his argument. If it is a tax on a tax, it is quite relevant; and I would suggest that Senator Sherry does not have a point of order at all.
—Order! This is a wide ranging debate and I would ask Senator McGauran to relate it to the answer given by Senator Kemp.

—I was very much developing my argument in regard to a tax on a tax on a tax. In fact, under your tax system we would have a triple tax on cars. You came in here yesterday feigning concern for the industry but, under your tax system, you would have a triple tax: a tariff and a wholesale sales tax on the stamp duty. So your system is a triple tax.

speech.para: You raised the question of what we are doing about the stamp duties by the states. With regard to state stamp duties, what did you do in your 13 years? We have a policy to abolish the stamp duties in the states. What better can you do than that? That is not a tax on a tax; that is an abolition of a tax. That is a whole abolition of a tax. That is our policy, and by 2001 that will be introduced. Why don't you get up and say that you would follow suit on that?

talk.start.para: —Senator McGauran, you might like to address the Chair, thank you very much.

—Madam Deputy President, you would be happy to know that this government's policy is to abolish the array of state taxes so that there will not be a tax on a tax at all. We will be abolishing bed taxes by 1 July next year. We will be abolishing the financial institutions tax by July of the following year.
—What about payroll tax?

—I would hope, Senator Sherry, that in the future payroll tax—which is a state tax, let us note—will also be tackled down the track. It is a debilitating tax also. We are abolishing the bed tax, the financial institutions tax and, by July 2000, we will be abolishing stamp duty on shares. We will be abolishing the bank accounts debit tax—another debilitating tax on business—by 1 July 2001. What better policy can you have than to abolish the states' stamp duties and the array of taxes you are talking about that have a tax on a tax, when the alternative policy is to maintain them in place and have a tax on a tax on a tax? You are triple taxers; we abolish the taxes.

speech.para: It is pretty clear that there may well be a transitional phase with the massive package that we are introducing, but we have in place the education system to make that transition as smooth as possible.
