talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: It is not possible to provide the requested information for the period since 3 March 1996 as FaCS has only been in existence since October 1998.

Records for the required period cover Centrelink, DSS and FaCS (which included new staff from Health and Family Services, Attorney Generals and the Institute of Family Studies). The size, function and location of these organisations differ greatly, and complete records are not available to this agency.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet: Freedom of Information Requests
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1526)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 20 September 1999:

question.para: (1) Of the requests for disclosure of information under the Freedom of Information Act dealt with by the department, or any agency in the portfolio, since 3 March 1996, how many requests have been made by: (a) a member of the House of Representatives; or (b) a member of the Senate.
(2) Of the cases relevant to (a) and (b) in (1), how many requests regarding access were: (a) partially successful; or (b) refused.
(3) Of the cases relevant to (a) and (b) in (1), how many requests regarding charges were: (a) partially successful; or (b) refused.

(4) Of the cases relevant to (2) and (3), how many of the department's or agency's written reasons for decision used, as grounds for refusal under the Act, a reference to members of Parliament having access to parliamentary processes to seek information from departments.

(5) Is the department, or any agency in the portfolio, aware of any provision contained in legislation, or departmental guidelines, or practice where the applicant's employment provision can be, or has been, used as grounds for refusing access to documents and/or refusing to waive charges, other than that set out in (4).

talk.start.para: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: I am advised that:
In relation to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet:
(4) None.

(5) In relation to the question of access, an applicant's employment status is generally irrelevant, save where access to certain documents may be granted to one applicant where it would not be granted to another applicant. For example, documents might ordinarily be exempted where they contained sensitive commercial information supplied by a company, but access would be given to an applicant who was acting on behalf of that company.

Where an applicant requests waiver of charges, the Freedom of Information Act requires decision-makers to consider whether full or part payment would cause financial hardship to the applicant or to a person on whose behalf the application was made. Income from employment may be a relevant factor in deciding whether or not to waive charges on the grounds of financial hardship.
In relation to the Commonwealth Ombudsman, the Official Secretary to the Governor-General, the Public Service and Merit Protection Commission, and the Merit Protection and Review Agency:
(5) As above.
The Office of National Assessments, the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security and the Auditor-General are exempt from the operation of the Freedom of Information Act.

subdebateinfo.title: Gold Medal Disability Strategy: Funding Allocation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1553)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 21 September 1999:

question.para: (1) (a) Can a breakdown be provided of expenditure of the $2.1 million allocated to the Gold Medal Disability Strategy; (b) how much was spent on the launch; (c) which disability groups were invited; and (d) what is the amount budgeted for the awards ceremony.
(2) What is the intended life of the strategy.
(3) Has the Government set targets for the number of businesses that it aims to see providing access to people with disabilities; if so, what is the timeframe under consideration.
(4) Can a list be provided of all firms invited to tender for the strategy's media/public relations.
(5) Why was there no formal consultation process with disability groups and people with disabilities in formulating the strategy.
(6) Did the Government consider alternatives to the awards-focus of the strategy; and (b) was any consideration given to the concept of demanding tangible outcomes from business.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) Strategy launch: $60,288 (actual); satellite broadcast to simultaneous State/Territory events: $26,950 (actual); eight Access Symposia in capital cities: $430,000 (est); information activities: $372,000 (est); Awards process: $225,000 (est); administrative costs: $870,000 (est. over 3 years); and $116,000 unallocated. Total: $2.1 million.
(c) National and state peak disability organisations were invited to attend either the national launch or the simultaneous State/Territory capital city events.
(2) Until July 2000.
(3) No, due to the wide variety of circumstances affecting individual businesses.
(4) Burson-Marsteller; Edelman Public Relations; Hill and Knowlton; IPR Shandwick; and Turnbull Porter Novelli.
(5) The Gold Medal Disability Access Strategy is an awareness campaign aimed at business, based on the very successful Prime Minister's Employer of the Year Awards.
(6) (a) No. (b) Yes. To be considered for a Gold Medal Disability Access Award businesses will be required to demonstrate tangible outcomes for people with disabilities.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Australian Taxation Office Web Site
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1554)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 21 September 1999:

question.para: (1) Why does the front page of the Australian Taxation Office web site on the goods and services tax (GST) only identify individuals, tax practitioners and businesses as the entry points to the site.

(2) Does the Treasurer agree that non-profit community organisations would not regard themselves as `businesses' and might therefore be misled into thinking that they were not going to be taxed through the GST.
(3) (a) Will a specific entry point be added for non-profit community groups on the web page; and (b) what advice and assistance is being provided specifically for non-profit community groups.

(4) (a) Is it fact, as stated on the web site, that the $500 million GST start up assistance will only be available `to assist small and medium business and the education and charities sectors'; and (b) why are other non-profit organisations excluded.

talk.start.para: —The following is provided to answer the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The inclusion of a clear entry point for charities and non-profit groups is planned to coincide with the release of sector specific publications planned for November 1999.

(2) The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) commenced a comprehensive education and communication campaign in July 1999 to inform the general public and the business communities about the changes to the tax system. The campaign has focused on who is required to register for GST and highlighted the issues involved for all organisations.

(3) (a) Refer to (1) above. (b) A range of mediums is being used to get information out to specific business and community sectors through general and industry specific publications, advertising and direct marketing, the media, infolines, the internet, seminar programs and individual client visits. The ATO has established a Charities Consultative Committee to clarify the main issues of concern to charities and non-profit community groups. Committee members have a broad range of expertise and are drawn from organisations across the sector. The Committee works in close partnership with the ATO's Charities Industries team which was set up to help the sector implement the new tax arrangements. The ATO is currently developing the content for public benevolent institutions and charities seminars to be launched in November 1999. These seminars will aim to cover the needs of non-profit community organisations but if necessary the ATO will conduct additional seminars specifically for these organisations later in November.

(4) (a) The ATO's tax reform website states "The Government is providing $500 million to assist small and medium business and the education and charities sectors make the transition to The New Tax System". This is not meant to imply that assistance is only available to those sectors. The first Fact Sheet on the GST Start-Up Assistance Office website (www.gststartup.gov.au) states that "The Government has set aside $500 million to assist small and medium enterprises, the community sector and educational bodies prepare for the introduction of the GST". The term `community sector' is used in its widest sense.
(b) Non-profit organisations are not excluded from GST start-up assistance. The $500 million start-up assistance package contains four programs:
- Business skills information and education ($40m)
- Adviser education ($7m)
- Organisation-delivered assistance ($130m)
- Direct assistance ($320m).

The products of the business skills information and education program will be widely available. The GST Start-Up Assistance Office has written to many non-profit organisations outside the small business, charity and education sectors asking them to lodge proposals for organisation-delivered assistance and to nominate advisers to be trained under the adviser education program. The Government will announce further details about the direct assistance program, including how to access funding, as this program is developed.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Legislation Amendments
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1556)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: (1) How many more amendments will the Government be making to the goods and services tax package of bills; and when will these amendments be tabled.
(2) (a) How many of the amendments are considered to be technical in nature; and (b) how many are considered to be substantive.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Government's aim is to have all amendments relating to the GST finalised before the end of the year. However, the Government reserves the right to make further changes and refinements to the legislation after that time if the need arises.
(2) See above answer.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Computer Software
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1559)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: When a consumer buys, for instance, a computer game the consumer is acquiring the right to use the software under a licensing agreement; this right is for the consumer's life: does this mean all such sales before 1 July 2000 are subject to the goods and services tax under section 14 of A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax Transition) Act 1999.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: No. The A New Tax System (Indirect Tax and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1999 includes amendments to clarify the taxation treatment of computer software. The amendments will ensure that, where the purchase of a computer game or software is accompanied by an indefinite license agreement, no GST will apply to such purchases made before 1 July 2000.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Price Rounding
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1561)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: When the goods and services tax is added to any item of supply and the price ends in two cents, for example, $45.22: (a) will that mean that the price is rounded down; and (b) conversely, if the price is $45.23 will it be rounded up.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The normal guidelines for rounding prices will apply.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Sales Warranties
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1567)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: (1) If a company offers a warranty as part of sale that are made before 1 July 2000 and the warranty extends beyond 1 July 2000, does the goods and services tax apply to the provision of the warranty.
(2) How does the taxpayer who offers the warranty go about determining the amount of GST that is payable in respect of the warranty.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (2) Where a warranty on goods sold prior to 1 July 2000 is provided as part of a separate agreement and the warranty period spans 1 July 2000, only that part of the warranty relating to the period from 1 July 2000 will be subject to GST.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Property Fringe Benefits
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1570)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: Is the goods and services tax payable on the provision of a property fringe benefit, for example, golf clubs, by an employer to an employee.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: It is the Government's intention that GST will not apply to the provision of a fringe benefit by an employer to an employee. As announced in ANTS, the FBT gross up formula will be adjusted to effectively recoup the GST input credit that was obtained by the employer in acquiring the fringe benefit.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Supermarket Goods
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1573)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: (1) When consumers buy a mixture of goods and services tax (GST) free goods and non-GST free goods, such as at a supermarket, how will they know which goods are GST free and which are not.
(2) Will supermarkets have to mark on their customer receipts which goods are GST free and which are not.
(3) If goods on a supermarket receipt do not have to be separately disclosed as subject to GST or GST free, how will consumers know whether they are being subjected to price exploitation or not.

talk.start.para: —The following answer is provided to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) As part of a broad information and education campaign, consumers are being informed of how they will be affected by The New Tax System. This includes how the GST will apply to different types of goods and services. A booklet containing information on the New Tax System was mailed directly to all households across Australia during September and October 1999.

(2) There will be no requirement for supermarkets to mark on receipts which goods are GST free and which are not. However, as it will be difficult for supermarkets to issue tax invoices on a date after the sale, it is likely that they will issue receipts to all customers that will satisfy the tax invoice requirements. The receipt will identify the goods that are subject to GST and show the total GST for the sale.

(3) The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) will monitor the price of goods and services to ensure they are adjusted properly for The New Tax System and will apply heavy fines for those responsible for price exploitation. A consumer that is not able to identify which goods have been subject to GST and has concerns about prices can contact the ACCC information line or obtain information from the ACCC website.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Income Tax Cuts
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1578)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: (1) Given that the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), Mr Macfarlane, recently warned that the goods and services tax (GST) could trigger an interest rate rise because of the fiscal stimulus caused by $12 billion worth of income tax cuts, what is the Government's assessment of the impact $12 billion worth of income tax cuts will have on the economy.
(2) Does the Government believe that a $12 billion fiscal stimulus could see the need for a tightening in monetary policy; if not, why not.
(3) If the $12 billion fiscal stimulus leads to inflationary pressures, does the Government believe that the RBA will be obliged to use monetary policy to contain the inflation threat.

(4) If the $12 billion fiscal stimulus puts the RBA's inflationary targets under threat, does the Government support the use of monetary policy in order to ensure that the inflationary targets are not broken.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Government will deliver $12 billion worth of income tax relief to the people of Australia commencing 1 July 2000—the largest personal income tax cuts in Australian history. This initiative is only one part of the Government's comprehensive overhaul of the Australian taxation system, as detailed in A New Tax System (ANTS), which is designed to greatly reduce distortions to choices about work, saving, spending and investment.
(2) The Government does not comment on the possible future course of interest rates.
(3) See answer to question 2.
(4) See answer to question 2.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Banking Compliance Costs
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1579)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: With reference to recent reports that, due to the goods and services tax (GST), banks will be faced with increased compliance costs of up to $300 million per year:
(1) Does the Government support this analysis
(2) With reference to this analysis, conducted by Mr Chris Murphy, which found that the banks would be $3000 million worse off, is Mr Murphy's analysis correct or incorrect.
(3) What flaws or errors, if any, has the Government found in Mr Murphy's analysis conducted for the banks.
(4) If the Government has found no errors or flaws in Mr Murphy's analysis, does this mean that Mr Murphy analysis is indeed correct.
(5) Does the Government believe Mr Murphy and his economic modelling to be credible; if so, then, is not the figure of $300 million in extra costs for banks also credible and believable.
(6) With reference to the Government's A New Tax System (ANTS) package estimates that the cost to banking will fall by $670 million or 2.8 per cent, does the Government still stand by this estimate.
(7) (a) How can the Government's estimate be a $670 million decrease while Mr Murphy has found a $300 million increase; and (b) how does the Government explain this $1 billion difference.
(8) With reference to the Government's estimate and Mr Murphy's estimate, who is to be believed, the Government or Mr Murphy.
(9) With reference to the Government's ANTS package estimates of a 10.6 per cent decrease in the price effect for banking, does the Government stand by this estimate.
(10) Will the banks be allowed to pass on, in full, the $300 million cost they claim the GST will impose on them by way of higher fees and charges.

(11) Will the Government support the Australian Consumer and Competition Commission taking action against any banks which increase fees and charges as a result of the GST, given the Government's estimate of decreasing costs for banks of $670 million
(12) How does the Government intend to ensure that the $670 million in cost savings for banks is passed on to consumers.
(13) In light of the Government's estimates, does the Government believe that bank fees and charges should fall and not rise as has been intimated by the banks.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (2) See answer to (1).
(3) See answer to (1).
(4) See answer to (1).
(5) See answer to (1).

(6) The Government stands by the estimates of the cost and price impact of its original tax reform package published in the A New Tax System (ANTS). Those estimates will have been affected by the agreement reached with the Australian Democrats in May 1999.
(7) See answer to (1).
(8) See answer to (1).
(9) See answer to (6).
(10) See answer to (1).

(11) The Australian Consumer and Competition Commission (ACCC) has issued guidelines setting out the circumstances where it will consider businesses have contravened the new price exploitation prohibition in 75AU of the Trade Practices Act 1974.
(12) See answer to (11).
(13) See answer to (1).

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Defraying of Compliance Costs
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1581)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: With reference to reports that the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants (ASCPA) has called for the granting of direct cash rebates to small businesses to help defray the cost of complying with the goods and services tax:
(1) Does the Government support the ASCPA's call; if not, why not.
(2) Does the granting of direct cash rebates to small business have any merit from a Government policy perspective; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Government will use part of the $500 million GST start-up assistance package to provide direct assistance to small and medium size enterprises. The New Tax System Advisory Board is providing advice on the most effective form of delivering direct assistance to enterprises.
(2) See response to (1).

subdebateinfo.title: Taxation: Trusts
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1583)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: With reference to the recent report that the Government's plan to tax trusts as companies will see up to $170 billion of assets transferred to new entities:
(1) Does the Government support this estimate as being credible.
(2) Is it still the Government's policy to tax all non-widely held trusts as companies, in particular, family discretionary trusts.
(3) Does the Government believe that family discretionary trusts are able to be used for maximum income splitting and therefore tax minimisation purposes; if not, why tax them as companies.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The report referred to the $171 billion worth of assets currently held in trusts. This estimate is as published by the Australian Taxation Office in the 1996-97 Taxation Statistics.
(2) The Government's policy is to tax trusts like companies, other than trusts specifically excluded from the unified entity regime and collective investment vehicles.

(3) Taxing trusts like companies under the unified entity regime will provide simplicity, clarity and fairness in the tax treatment of trusts and greater integrity in the operation of the business tax system.

subdebateinfo.title: Taxation: Trusts
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1584)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: (1) Is Mr John Hoare, a legal adviser to the Queensland National Party, correct in claiming that the proposal to tax trusts as companies is equivalent to a hidden death duty and wealth tax; if not, why is he incorrect.
(2) Is Mr Hoare seen by the Government as a credible legal commentator on the taxation of trusts proposal, or is he just spreading misinformation on the Government's proposals.
(3) Can the Government confirm whether Mr Hoare has briefed members of the Government on the taxation of trusts proposal; if so, who has he briefed.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Claims that taxing trusts like companies is equivalent to introducing a hidden death duty and wealth tax are incorrect.

A wealth tax is essentially a tax imposed upon the stock of a taxpayer's wealth. A death duty is essentially a wealth tax imposed on a taxpayer's stock of wealth when they die. The proposal to tax trusts like companies will not have these features.
Mr Hoare's is not currently a legal advisor to the Queensland National Party.
(2) See answer to Question 1.
(3) Members of the Government receive representations from members of the public on various matters, including taxation.

subdebateinfo.title: New Car Registrations
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1585)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: (1) Is the Government concerned at the recent drop in new car registrations in July 1999 being 11 per cent lower than July 1998 and August 1999 being 10 per cent lower than August 1998.

(2) Does the Government agree that part of the reason for the decline in new car registrations is attributable to a buyers' strike as consumers await the anticipated fall in new car prices due to the abolition of wholesale sales tax (WST) on new cars from 1 July 2000; if not, why not.
(3) Is the Government considering any changes to phase in the WST abolition for new cars in order to avoid a buyers' strike.
(4) Does the Government support calls by the motor vehicle industry to make changes to the Government's planned abolition of WST on new motor vehicles.

(5) Is it the Government's view that the 11 per cent and 10 per cent falls in new car registrations are more likely due to a slowing domestic economy than a goods and services tax-induced buyers' strike.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) A decline in new motor vehicle sales in 1999 is not unexpected in the wake of the record sales levels in 1998.
(2) See (1) above.
(3) See (1) above.
(4) See (1) above.
(5) See (1) above.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Input Taxation Inputs
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1586)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: Will the Government be reviewing its decision to deny full input tax credits to goods and services tax (GST)-registered entities who purchase new motor vehicles in the 2 years following the introduction of the GST.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: No.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Input Tax Credits
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1587)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: Can the Government confirm that input tax credits will not form part of assessable income, as claimed by Price Waterhouse Coopers tax expert Mr Geoffrey Lehmann.

talk.start.para: —The following answer is provided to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The Government has recently introduced legislation which sets out the rules for taking GST into account in calculating taxable income. The proposed amendments to the income tax law are contained in Schedule 3 to the A New Tax System (Indirect Tax and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1999, which was introduced on 30 September 1999.

The amendments will exclude GST liability from amounts included in assessable income. Deductible amounts will exclude the GST from expenditure incurred to the extent of the entity's input tax credit entitlement. GST will be deductible only to the extent that the entity is not entitled to claim the corresponding input tax credit, for example, because the entity has an annual turnover of less than $50 000 and has chosen not to register for GST purposes.

The exclusion of GST components from transaction amounts in calculating income tax liability is the method used in New Zealand and in the UK (in relation to VAT). The accounting profession, through the Urgent Issues Group, has also recently expressed support for accounting for sales of goods and services net of GST and for purchases net of recoverable GST, that is, after allowing for input tax credits.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Taxable Income
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1588)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: If a goods and services tax (GST)-registered entity makes GST taxable sales of $110,000 and has $99,000 worth of GST taxable expenses, how will the net GST payment of $1,000 be treated for tax purposes: will it be deductible or non-deductible.

talk.start.para: —The following answer is provided to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The Government has recently introduced legislation which sets out the rules for taking GST into account in calculating taxable income. The proposed amendments to the income tax law are contained in Schedule 3 to the A New Tax System (Indirect Tax and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1999, which was introduced on 30 September 1999.

The amendments will exclude GST liability from amounts included in assessable income. Deductible amounts will exclude the GST from expenditure incurred to the extent of the entity's input tax credit entitlement. GST will be deductible only to the extent that the entity is not entitled to claim the corresponding input tax credit, for example, because the entity has an annual turnover of less than $50,000 and has chosen not to register for GST purposes.

In the honourable senator's example, the GST registered entity will have assessable income of $100,000 and deductions of $90,000 leaving a taxable income of $10,000. The entity's actual expenditure of $99,000 is reduced by $9,000, reflecting its input tax credit entitlement from that expenditure, to determine the deductible amount.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Depreciation Expenses
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1589)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: If a goods and services tax (GST)-registered entity buys an item of plant for $1 100 000 which is GST inclusive, will the $100 000 GST form part of the cost base for depreciation purposes.

talk.start.para: —The following answer is provided to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The Government has recently introduced legislation which sets out the rules for taking GST into account in calculating taxable income. The proposed amendments to the income tax law are contained in Schedule 3 to the A New Tax System (Indirect Tax and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1999, which was introduced on 30 September 1999.

In the example contained in the honourable senator's question, the cost base of the plant for depreciation purposes will be $1 million. This assumes that the entity would be entitled to an input tax credit of $100 000, that is, assuming the plant was acquired wholly for a creditable purpose. If the acquisition of the plant was only partly creditable, the input tax credit would be reduced, and the cost base of the plant for depreciation purposes increased, by the same amount.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Input Taxation Credits
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1590)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: Given that input tax credits on the purchase of a motor vehicle will not be able to be claimed by a goods and services tax (GST)-registered entity: will the GST component of a new car purchase form part of the cost balance for depreciation purposes; if not, will the GST paid be claimable within the tax period in which the asset was acquired or will the GST input tax credit have to be claimed back over the estimated life of the asset.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: Depreciation is calculated on the cost of the motor vehicle. The availability of input tax credits to a registered business (full or partial) reduce the cost of a new motor vehicle to a registered business and need to be taken into account when calculating depreciation.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Regulation Impact Statement
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1591)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: (1) With reference to the Government's goods and services tax Regulation Impact Statement, which estimates recurrent goods and services tax compliance costs per business of only $385 per year for the 2001-02 financial year: What is the Government's estimate for the 2000-01 financial year.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The aggregate net recurrent GST compliance costs for all firms have been estimated at $385 million for 2001-02.

subdebateinfo.title: Small Business: Computerised Accounting Systems
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1594)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: With reference to small businesses that run manual accounting systems.
(1) Does the Government believe that it will be better for them to move to a computerised accounting system in order to account for the goods and services tax (GST).
(2) Does the Government agree that the GST will encourage non-computerised small businesses to become computer literate.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) This is a decision for each business to make.
(2) See answer to (1).

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Domestic Air Travel
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1595)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1999:

question.para: With reference to the Government's A New Tax System package estimates that air and space transport (price effect) will fall by 0.8 per cent:
(1) Does the Government still stand by this estimate.

(2) With reference to Qantas' prediction that the goods and services tax (GST) on domestic travel will see a significant flow through: Why should there be a significant flow through of the GST, no doubt into higher airfares, when the Government's own estimates have predicted a 0.8 per cent fall.

(3) If Qantas, or any other airline, increases domestic airfares as a result of the GST: (a) will it be subject to action by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission; and (b) will the Government support such action.
(4) Given the Government's estimates, shouldn't airline travel at worse remain static in price and at best experience marginal falls.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Government stands by the estimates of the cost and price impact of its original tax reform package published in the A New Tax System (ANTS). Those estimates have been affected by the agreement reached with the Australian Democrats in May 1999.
(2) The estimate of a 0.8 per cent increase in the prices of industry 64.01 Air and space transport is an estimate of the average price change of the industry group as a whole.

(3) Airlines are permitted to charge GST on contracts for only that portion of the contract to be performed on or after 1 July 2000. Any price changes that contravene Part VB of the Trade Practices Act 1974 will be subject to remedial action by the ACCC.
(4) See answer to (2).

subdebateinfo.title: Television: Captioning
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1597)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 24 September 1999:

question.para: How much of the television coverage of the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games and of the celebrations of the Centenary of Federation will be captioned for the deaf and hearing impaired.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: On 13 July 1999, the Seven Network, the rights holder for the broadcast of the Sydney Olympic Games, announced plans to close caption all prime time free to air coverage of the Games. During the period of the Olympic broadcasts, closed captioning will be provided on weekdays from 7pm to 11pm and on weekends between 1pm and 11pm. Both the Opening and Closing Ceremonies fall within these times and will therefore be captioned.

In relation to the captioning of television coverage of the Centenary of Federation, broadcasters have not announced their plans for the broadcast of events associated with the Centenary of Federation celebrations. However, given that a captioning standard, associated with the implementation of digital television, will apply to commercial and national broadcasters transmitting in the digital mode from 1 January 2001, certain programming related to the celebration of the Centenary of Federation may be required under the standard to be captioned.

subdebateinfo.title: Fruit Fly Eradication Program
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1598)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 27 September 1999:

question.para: (1) Has the papaya fruit fly eradication program in north Queensland been completed.
(2) Is the government confident that all papaya fruit fly have been eliminated.
(3) What has been the total cost of the eradication program since the incursion of the papaya fruit fly was first detected.
(4) In broad terms, how were these costs spread across the various elements of the eradication program, for example,
costs of chemicals, labour costs, et cetera.
(5) Have there been any claims for compensation made against the Commonwealth or its agencies and/or any other person or entity because of the entry of the papaya fruit fly into north Queensland.
(6) Does the government have any figures for losses suffered by farmers following the entry of the papaya fruit fly into north Queensland; if so, what are they.
(7) Did the Government make any assessment of the impact of the eradication program on organic fruit and vegetable growers in north Queensland; if so, can a copy of the assessment be provided.
(8) Has the Government received any reports of health problems associated with the use of chemicals in the eradication program.

(9) Has the Government received any reports of complaints about the use of chemicals, liquid or gas, on fruit or vegetables necessary to enable these products to be exported from north Queensland during the period following the discovery of the papaya fruit fly.
(10) What measures are now in place to ensure that there will not be further incursions of the papaya fruit fly into north Queensland.

(11) How do these measures compare with measures in place for each of the 10 years, prior to the discovery of the papaya fruit fly in north Queensland, in terms of: (a) the cost of any monitoring program; (b) the nature of these monitoring, that is, what kind of traps were used and where; and (c) the reason for the breakdown in these programs which allowed for the entry of the papaya fruit fly into north Queensland.

(12) (a) What kinds of certification and/or approval are necessary in order to ensure confidence in the claim that papaya fruit fly have been eliminated from north Queensland; and (b) from whom does the certification and/or approval have to be obtained.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The papaya fruit fly (PFF) eradication campaign was completed when formal recognition of eradication was declared in May 1999. Area freedom status was achieved in August 1998. All that remains to be finalised under the eradication program is the documentation of the campaign and the preparation and publication of scientific papers.

(2) A scientific Technical Advisory panel, which comprised fruit fly scientists with international and national recognition, was established to oversight the scientific activities of the eradication program. Acting on the advice of this panel, the criteria for establishing the eradication of the pest were developed and implemented. This included maintaining the intensive monitoring for the presence of the pest for over twelve months following the last detection of a wild fly. Given that this criterion was met and papaya fruit fly has not been detected in the wild since July 1997, the government is confident that the pest has been eradicated.

(3) The total cost to the Commonwealth and State/Territory governments under the national cost sharing agreement for the eradication campaign was $33.54 million. In addition, the Queensland Government provided an additional $3.8 million for the purchase and refurbishment of a building for fruit fly disinfestation research in Cairns, and a further $4.5 million to support affected horticultural growers in north Queensland, through waiving of government service charges.

(4) Labour and non-labour costs for the cost shared component of the eradication program were approximately $23.5 million [70%] (labour), $7.75 million [23%] (consumables, including chemicals, supplementary traps and other equipment for fruit fly control), $2.25 million [7%] (capital).

(5) There have been a total of five claims for compensation made in relation to the PFF program. Two claims related to damages arising out of the actual eradication program. One was a minor claim relating the alleged death of goldfish in a garden pond which was settled. The other involves alleged damage to a number of coffee crops near Mareeba.

There have also been three other claims lodged for compensation for damages arising out of the application of post harvest quarantine treatments required for the movement of produce out of the PFF quarantine area. Two claims have been settled and the other is the subject of current civil action.

(6) The cost to the north Queensland horticultural industry resulting from the PFF outbreak has been estimated by industry at approximately $100 million. This primarily consists of initial lost markets and the costs of the implementation of PFF quarantine protocols.

The government has no direct figures on the amount of any losses that may have been suffered by farmers as a result of the PFF outbreak. In the initial stages of the outbreak the estimate of the potential economic loss to the Australian horticultural industry had the pest not been eradicated was calculated by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) to be $73.51 million annually.

(7) The impact of the eradication program on the organic fruit industry was considered during the program. Every effort was made to accommodate the organic industry in meeting their strict protocols, minimising market disruption for organic produce and still maintaining the eradication program. Extensive consultation was maintained with organic growers throughout the eradication program.
No formal economic assessment was undertaken.

(8) There were a number of complaints lodged by the plant industries and the general public relating to the chemicals being used in the eradication program. The complaints lodged by plant industries related to workplace health and safety issues arising from the requirement for post harvest chemical disinfestation of produce leaving the quarantine area. These complaints were dealt with on an individual basis, working closely with the local Health and Workplace Health and Safety agencies.

Complaints from the public included concerns relating to the use of chemical insecticides in the eradication treatments. These were addressed through the formation of a PFF Health and Environmental Liaison Group. In addition, close collaboration with the National Registration Authority (NRA) on the use of the eradication chemicals was maintained throughout the program. The NRA also conducted an independent audit into the use of chemicals in the eradication program. This audit established that the eradication program was being conducted in an effective and safe manner. In conjunction with the local Queensland Health office, the NRA also established an adverse chemical consequences register relating to the eradication program. However, the NRA received no reports of adverse chemical consequences.

(9) Apart from the Workplace Health and Safety issues mentioned in the answer to question 8 (above), there have not been any formal complaints about the use of chemicals on fruits and vegetables associated with the PFF quarantine requirements.

(10) The Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has two operating groups with responsibilities with regard to exotic pests and diseases. One group has responsibility for the exclusion of exotic pests and diseases and in the event that there is a breach in the quarantine barrier, the other group is responsible for the management of incursions of exotic pests and diseases.

The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) has prime responsibility for the exclusion of exotic pests and diseases from Australia. Measures in place to ensure that no further incursions of papaya fruit fly occur include the airports program, aimed at preventing people entering Australia carrying items of quarantine concern, such as fruit and vegetables that may harbour papaya fruit fly. The import clearance program facilitates the entry of among other things agricultural products from overseas and ensures that such products are free of pests and diseases.

The National Office of Animal and Plant Health (NOAPH) administers a national fruit fly surveillance program designed to identify and define incursions of targeted exotic fruit fly pests, including papaya fruit fly, entering through international pathways at ports and associated urban areas. It is the aim of this program to ensure that, where incursions of papaya fruit fly and other exotic fruit fly species occur, they are detected quickly enabling a response strategy to be rapidly implemented.

The Queensland Department of Primary Industries administers the operational aspect of the national program, under contract to NOAPH, as well as administering a supplementary fruit fly surveillance program which operates in other centres at high risk of fruit fly incursion, such as the Sunshine Coast and Gold Coast.

The Northern Australia Quarantine Strategy (NAQS) within AQIS performs crop and field surveys throughout northern Australia, Papua New Guinea and Indonesia to provide data on the pest status of these regions for the formulation of quarantine programs to combat such pests. Papaya fruit fly is a known pest of the South East Asian region.

(11) (a) The cost of the national surveillance program in the financial year 1999/2000 will be $464,165. There is also a limited outlay of funds for consumable items associated with surveillance such as traps and other trapping equipment. The national surveillance program has been in operation for each of the financial years 1996/97, 1997/98 and 1998/99 at a cost similar to that of the current financial year. Before the 1996/97 financial year, there was no national surveillance program in operation.
No figures associated with financing the Northern Monitoring [see (11) (b) below] are available for the years sought.

(b) Surveillance for exotic fruit flies in northern Australia has been carried out since the mid-1970s, initially under the Northern Monitoring Program. This program was largely carried out by state and territory departments in the region, funded by the Commonwealth quarantine authority. Initially, the program maintained surveillance sites along Australia's northern coastline between Derby in Western Australia and the Torres Strait. Following the release of the 1991 review commissioned by NAQS, a decision was made not to undertake surveillance in Cairns under the NAQS program. This decision was made on the basis that surveillance in settled areas was not a NAQS responsibility but should be considered in the broader context of surveillance at ports of entry.

The first surveillance program with national coverage was initiated in 1996. The program, as it has operated since 1996, provides a minimum 5 km density of trap sites in all major and minor trafficked `first port of call' ports. The network includes over 1,600 traps directly administered by the National Office of Animal and Plant Health and serviced by the state departments of agriculture/ primary industry in Western Australia, Northern Territory, Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria. Tasmania and South Australia carry out more extensive surveillance in port cities and towns to support those states' pest free area programs. The NAQS carries out surveillance in the more remote areas and port city areas in northern Australia. Traps are maintained in the urban areas of: Sydney, Newcastle, Wollongong, Yamba, Coffs Harbour, Darwin, Gove, Groote, Brisbane, Cairns, Townsville, Gladstone, Mackay, Bundaberg, Weipa, Thursday Island, Mourilyan Harbour, Karumba, Adelaide, Port Lincoln, Port Augusta, Port Pirie, Whyalla, Ceduna, Hobart, Launceston, Devonport/ Burnie, Melbourne/Westonport, Geelong, Portland, Albany, Bunbury, Esperance, Perth/Freemantle, Geraldton, Dampier, Karratha, Carnavon, Broome, Wydham, Derby and Port Hedland.

Three trap types are located at each surveillance site. Each trap type contains a lure type specific to one fruit fly group. Methyl eugenol lures are used for papaya fruit fly and related species, capi-lure for Mediterranean fruit fly and related species and cue-lure is used to detect Queensland fruit fly and related species. The trap types used in fruit fly surveillance differ in architecture and have specific applications depending on the environment and climate they are used in. Within the national surveillance system the so-called `Steiner', `Lynfield' and `Jackson' traps are utilised.

(c) It was recognised by the Consultative Committee that was formed to manage the eradication campaign for PFF, that the likely pathway that led to the establishment of the PFF was the illegal entry of fruit carried by a private individual through the quarantine barrier.

It is possible that PFF may have been present in the Cairns region for two or more years before the species was identified. There was no structured fruit fly surveillance system, utilising traps with lures, operating in the region.

(12) (a) There was no pre-established national or international certification or approval mechanism in place to ensure confidence in the claim that PFF has been eradicated from north Queensland. In the case of PFF, a specific criterion was agreed upon, nationally, to ensure confidence in eradication claims. The Papaya Fruit Fly Technical Advisory Panel considered PFF to be eradicated if a minimum period of nine months of nil detections was reached, in the absence of eradication measures, including one peak activity season for fruit flies (summer). A period of 20 months of nil detections had elapsed at the time of declaration of eradication.

The International Plant Protection Convention (IPPC), under the Food and Agriculture Organisation, has associated standards for phytosanitary measures, including a standard for pest surveillance. These standards are recognised by the World Trade Organisation. The particular standard relating to pest surveillance encompasses general requirements for achieving and maintaining pest free areas. The standard provides a scientific framework for national governments to assess claims of pest freedom as the need arises. Australia has met this general standard in regard to eradicating PFF and maintaining a pest free area in the eradication zone. To remain assured of the PFF-free status of fruit exported from Australia, AQIS inspects such fruit for freedom from quarantine pests and documents this through phytosanitary certification issued in accordance with IPPC requirements.

(b) Endorsement of the eradication criterion for PFF within north Queensland was made by the National Papaya Fruit Fly Consultative Committee. All states and territories of Australia endorsed the declaration of eradication through the committee processes working under the auspices of the Standing Committee on Agriculture and Resource Management.
The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service sought and received the endorsement of international trading partners of the criterion and outcome of the eradication campaign.

subdebateinfo.title: Falun Gong
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1638)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 30 September 1999:

question.para: (1) Did the Minister or the Prime Minister raise the issue of the Falun Gong with the President of China Jiang Zemin, during his recent visit to Australia.
(2) Can the Minister outline any action the Australian Government has taken to date, regarding the arrests and allegations of torture of practitioners of Falun Gong in China.
(3) With reference to reports from the Falun Gong which indicate that hundreds of thousands of practitioners are currently being held, does the Minister have any confirmation of these figures.
(4) Is the Minister aware of when the trials for the imprisoned Falun Gong practitioners are being conducted.

(5) Given that if the Falun Gong practitioners are found guilty of subversion the penalty could be death, has any representation to the Chinese Government been made to ensure that the trials are fair and open and can be monitored by international and human rights bodies.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) No

(2) The Australian Government has raised its concerns about the treatment of Falungong with the Chinese government: first, to the Chinese Charg d'Affaires in Canberra on 23 July 1999; secondly, to a senior official of the Chinese Foreign Ministry in Beijing on 29 July; and thirdly, in a number of senior-level meetings during the third round of the Australia-China Human Rights Dialogue, held in China from 16-20 August. On each occasion, we told the Chinese that, although we take no position on the beliefs of Falungong, we consider that actions taken against its adherents are in breach of the international human rights covenants which China has signed.
(3) I have no confirmation of the numbers of Falungong adherents currently in detention in China. On 28 September, Amnesty International put the number at "hundreds".
(4) I have no concrete information on the timing of trials.

(5) The Australian Government's strong view that all trials should be fair and open and conducted in accordance with standards laid out in international covenants is well known to the Chinese authorities and has been conveyed to them on numerous occasions.

subdebateinfo.title: Gold Coast Holdings Pty Ltd: Australian Securities Commission Investigation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1640)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, upon notice, on 29 September 1999:

question.para: (1) With reference to the company Gold Coast Holdings Pty Ltd, has the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) held investigations into the company; if so: (a) has the ASC completed the investigation; and (b) did the ASC find any breaches of the law.
(2) Does the ASC intend to refer the results of the investigation to the Director of Public Prosecution (DPP).

(3) With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 272 (Senate Hansard , 5 December 1996, p.6868) and the company Power Engine Flush Australia Pty Ltd, was the company ever prosecuted by the DPP as a result of a referral by the Australian Companies and Securities Commission; if so, what was the result of the prosecution.

(4) Is the former director of the company Power Engine Flush Australia Pty Ltd, Mr Samuel Papotto, a director of Gold Coast Holdings Pty Ltd, or has he ever been a director; if so, when did he become a director.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Financial Services and Regulation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) and (2) Normally, the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC), does not comment on current issues which it may or may not be examining. However, as this matter has already been canvassed publicly, ASIC has advised that it is assisting the liquidator of Gold Coast Holdings Pty Ltd to obtain the books and records of the company and expects to be in a position to assess the matter when the final report of the liquidator has been lodged.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's questions is as follows:

answer.para: Radio Australia currently broadcasts 19 hours/day to Eastern Indonesia, including East Timor (via Shepparton). An additional hour is broadcast, Monday to Friday, from the same site for the Australian defence forces in East Timor.

subdebateinfo.title: McFarlane, Mr Alistair: Boiwek-Almudj Sacred Site Area Assessment
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1654)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 30 September 1999:

question.para: (1) What was the criteria used in selecting Mr Alistair McFarlane to assess the Mirrar people's application under section 10 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984 in relation to the Boiwek-Almudj sacred site area.
(2) What are the attributes which make Mr McFarlane suitable for this appointment.
(3) What are the terms and conditions of Mr McFarlane's appointment.
(4) Were the Mirrar people consulted over this appointment; if so, how.

(5) Did the Mirrar people approve of the selection of Mr McFarlane; if not, does the appointment accord with the Government's commitment to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO) World Heritage Committee to engage in constructive dialogue with the traditional owners over assessment of the Boiwek-Almudj sacred site.
(6) Has the appointment been advised to the UNESCO World Heritage Committee.
(7) What is the process by which Mr McFarlane will conduct his assessment.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Under section 10 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984, I must nominate a person to write a report on s.10 matters for my consideration. Mr McFarlane was chosen as the section 10 reporter on his merits. He is an experienced lawyer, widely respected in legal circles for his objectivity and fairness, and he possesses extensive, highly relevant experience in Aboriginal heritage and native title issues.
(2) This question has been answered in question 1.
(3) This question is no longer relevant.

(4) The Mirrar people were consulted on the appointment of a section 10 reporter by me personally on several occasions. On returning from the World Heritage Committee meeting in Paris, I travelled to Jabiru on 26 July 1999 to specifically talk with officials of the Gundjehmi Aboriginal Corporation about on-going issues relating to Jabiluka, including the appointment of a s.10 reporter. I again met with officials of the Gundjehmi Aboriginal Corporation on 10 September 1999 to discuss the appointment of the section 10 reporter. In addition, I designated a senior Officer from my Department to liaise with the Mirrar and other interested parties to ensure the process moved ahead in a sensitive manner and to help facilitate the continuation of the consultation process.

(5) The Mirrar people questioned the selection of Mr McFarlane, which I addressed in full in correspondence to them. While the section 10 application has been withdrawn by the Mirrar, the Government remains open and committed to the continuation of constructive dialogue with the traditional owners over the assessment of the Boyweg-Almudj sacred site.

(6) The appointment of Mr McFarlane was advised by letter to Mr Mounir Bouchenaki, Director of the UNESCO World Heritage Centre in Paris, on 7 October 1999. Mr Bouchenaki will pass this information on to the World Heritage Committee.
(7) With the application withdrawn, this question is no longer relevant.

subdebateinfo.title: Business Taxation Review: Australian Stock Exchange
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1661)

question.para: With reference to the recent Review of Business Taxation by Mr John Ralph:

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

subdebateinfo.title: Polling Booths: Disabled Access
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1662)

talk.start.para: asked the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 6 October 1999:

question.para: (1) How many polling booths at the 1998 federal election were inaccessible by wheelchair.
(2) How does this compare with the 1996 and 1993 federal elections.
(3) Does the Australian Electoral Commission have a strategy to increase accessibility for disabled people at polling booths; if so, can a copy be provided.
(4) What voting provisions are made for people in wheelchairs where access is not available.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) For the 1998 Federal election a total of 3,377 polling places had no wheelchair access. It should be noted that, for this election, a new system of placing polling places into three wheelchair access categories (full access, access with minimal assistance, no access) was introduced. The categories are identified on all polling place advertising. The change followed meetings and discussions with the Commonwealth Disability Commissioner and also a desire by the AEC to accurately reflect Australian standard (AS 1428) access requirements. While many buildings do not fully comply with AS 1428, they may still allow for reasonable wheelchair access.

(2) In 1993, 4,967 polling places had no wheelchair access. In 1996, 3,771 polling places had no wheelchair access. The significant improvement between 1993 and 1996 was as a result of both efforts to locate and utilise polling places with higher levels of wheelchair access and a full review of polling places to more accurately classify them. As wheelchair access levels constantly change due to building improvements and/or replacement and new buildings, the review of polling place locations is an ongoing process between major electoral events.

(3) Yes. A copy of the Commission's Disability Discrimination Plan, which has recently been subject to broad consultation within the disability community, can be provided. The plan sets out the Commission's strategy for increasing the number of polling places with wheelchair access. The plan is also available on the Commission's web site aec.gov.au

(4) There are three options for voters in situations where wheelchair access is not available. With the first option, a voter can apply for and then cast a postal vote from their own place of residence. With the second option, pre-poll voting, the Commission ensures that pre-poll voting centres have wheelchair access and are normally open for a period of two weeks prior to election day. In regard to the third option, an amendment to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 just prior to the 1998 Federal election enabled Presiding Officers to take voting material and a ballot box outside a polling place to a voter with a disability so that they could still vote without having to enter the polling place.

subdebateinfo.title: Film Production: Backdated Taxation Liability
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1689)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 October 1999:

question.para: (1) Is the Treasurer aware that a number of small investors in the film production Michael have had claims in relation to their investments under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 refused by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO), resulting in taxation liabilities dating back to 1995.

(2) Is the Treasurer aware of any advance opinions or private binding rulings made by the ATO in relation to this production; if so, can the Treasurer advise: (a) when these opinions or rulings were made; and (b) what they said about investments in this project under the Act.

(3) Has the ATO made any investigations into the companies involved in this film, Kamisha Productions Limited and Shooting Star Holdings Pty Ltd; if not, will the ATO investigate whether these companies misled investors about the allowableness under the Act for investment in this production.

talk.start.para: —The following answer is provided to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The ATO has been conducting a review of claims made by investors for film production costs. The review has been examining claims for deductions, under the general deduction provisions of the income tax law, of amounts that are claimed to be contributions for the production of overseas films.

The ATO decision to amend assessments of participants is consistent with the self assessment system under which assessments are issued on the basis of information in a taxpayers' return. The Commissioner of Taxation (the Commissioner) is authorised to amend an assessment if he subsequently becomes aware that there has been a tax shortfall or if a taxpayer has overpaid an amount of tax.
(2) The Commissioner has advised me that he is not aware of any advance opinions or private binding rulings in relation to the production of Michael.
(3) Due to the secrecy provisions of the tax law the Commissioner is unable to provide me with any details concerning the taxation affairs of the companies involved with this film.

However, the Commissioner advises me that the prospectuses issued in relation to the film make it clear that the tax consequences `may not ultimately be as anticipated' and that the Commissioner may `as a matter of administrative policy, or otherwise, disallow deductions'.

subdebateinfo.title: Human Rights: Australia-China Dialogue
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1693)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 21 October 1999:

question.para: With reference to the bilateral talks on human rights which took place between an Australian Government delegation and a Chinese Government delegation in China in 1999:
(1) Was an agenda agreed to by the delegations at the talks.
(2) Was a record taken of the discussions between the two delegations.
(3) Can the Minister specify each topic discussed by the delegations and, in respect of each such topic: (a) any conclusion agreed to; and (b) the outcome of the discussion.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) A broad outline of topics to be covered was agreed in advance of the third round of the dialogue, held in China from 16—21 August 1999. There were nine separate meetings with ministries and agencies during the first three days: these meetings did not have discrete agendas.
(2) Each side took separate notes of the discussions.

(3) The main topics fell into three broad categories: domestic, regional and international. Under the domestic heading, Australian concerns about the following matters were discussed: restrictions on the freedoms of assembly, association, expression and religion (for example, the detention of leaders of the China Democracy Party, the "reform through labour" system, the treatment of adherents of the Falun Gong, independent trade unionists, members of the unofficial Catholic church and Protestant house churches); the human rights situation in Tibet and Xinjiang and that affecting other ethnic and religious minorities in China; the welfare of the boy identified by the Dalai Lama as the new Panchen Lama; the use of the death penalty; reports of the use of torture and other degrading practices; problems in law enforcement, including the execu tion of judgements; women's rights; and reports of coercion in the implemention of China's family planning policies. The timetable for China's ratification of the two main human rights instruments, new activities under the Human Rights and Technical Assistance Program, and a number of other matters were also discussed. Multilateral and regional human rights mechanisms and activities were principally covered at the meeting with the Foreign Ministry.

(a) For the most part, the topics did not lend themselves to agreed conclusions. In some cases, as for example on the death penalty, the positions were diametrically opposed. In others, there was more common ground.
(b) The two sides agreed on new activities under the Human Rights and Technical Assistance Program. More details can be found on DFAT's human rights website at www.dfat.gov.au/hr/
